19.92.text: Christmas University Challenge. Asking the questions, Jeremy Paxman.

29.08.text: Hello. Tis the season to be jolly,

31.56.text: but despite that, 14 groups of distinguished alumni have opted

35.52.text: to spend time answering questions instead of guzzling mince pies.

39.68.text: Now only the best two of those teams remain and,

42.72.text: in a little under half an hour, one of them

45.16.text: will have earned the right to call themselves series champions

48.16.text: and to enjoy the victor's glass of eggnog in the green room afterwards.

52.80.text: Now the team from the University of Hull beat Newcastle University

56.12.text: in round one and Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford, in the semifinals,

59.80.text: on which occasion they shone on seaside resorts,

63.16.text: St Bartholomew and the land borders of Slovenia.

66.48.text: They're represented again by two writers, an actor,

72.56.text: Hello, I'm Rosie Millard. I read English and drama at Hull.

78.00.text: I'm a journalist and I'm chair of the Hull City Of Culture 2017.

82.68.text: Hello, my name is Malcolm Sinclair.

84.28.text: I graduated in 1972 in drama and theology.

88.52.text: I'm president of Equity trade union and I'm an actor.

92.56.text:
- And this is their captain. 
- Hello, I'm Dame Jenni Murray.

95.96.text: I graduated in 1972 in French and drama

99.76.text: and I present Woman's Hour on BBC Radio 4.

105.32.text: I graduated from Hull in '84 with a maths degree.

108.60.text: I was a pop star for a while, but now I'm a children's author,

111.48.text: a travel writer and I make a mean cup of tea.

119.12.text: The team from Trinity Hall, Cambridge,

121.32.text: defeated Balliol College, Oxford, in round one

123.88.text: and the University of Edinburgh in round two.

126.00.text: They delivered their answers with the same degree of aplomb,

129.24.text: regardless of whether they were completely wrong,

131.52.text: as they were on the okapi and its predators, or right,

134.88.text: as they frequently were on subjects

136.84.text: ranging from Dido, Queen of Carthage, to Joe Orton.

140.56.text: Their team comprises two athletes, a novelist and critic, and an actor.

147.16.text: Hello, I'm Tom James. I graduated in engineering in 2007.

151.04.text: I used to be an oarsman for the Great British rowing team

153.52.text: and now am a management consultant.

157.04.text: I'm Emma Pooley. I graduated in 2005 in engineering.

160.00.text: I'm a retired professional cyclist, now a professional triathlete.

166.12.text: I graduated in 1976 in English and I'm a novelist and critic.

172.28.text: I graduated in Anglo-Saxon, Norse and Celtic in 1999 and I'm now an actor.

182.88.text: Right, it's the final, so let's not waste any time

185.56.text: and crack on with a first starter for ten.

194.00.text: are variations of which Swiss dish, the Latin meaning half...

199.80.text:
- Fondue. 
- Fondue is correct, yes. 
- APPLAUSE

204.92.text: So you get the first set of bonuses, Trinity Hall. They're on bridges.

208.60.text: Built in limestone around 1600 by Antonio Contino, which bridge

213.52.text: in Venice connects the Doge's Palace to the Prigioni Nuove or New Prison?

219.08.text:
- Bridge of Sighs? 
- It's the only bridge I know in Venice.

225.60.text: crosses the Vltava river in which European city?

236.04.text: Which is the oldest of Florence's six bridges over the Arno?

239.68.text: It's noted for its roofed passageway flanked by rows of shops.

243.92.text:
- Ponte Vecchio. 
- Correct. Ten points for this.

246.64.text: What two-word English term is used in Japan to refer

252.08.text: have moved a number of public holidays

257.04.text: This system is not to be confused with a Madchester band

260.88.text:
- whose members include Mark Berry and... 
- BUZZER

264.72.text:
- Happy Mondays? 
- Happy Mondays is correct, yes. 
- APPLAUSE

269.96.text: So you get another set of bonuses, Trinity Hall,

275.68.text: Puyi was the 12th and final ruler of which Chinese dynasty?

279.52.text: He became titular ruler of the Japanese puppet state

286.28.text:
- OK. 
- So the dynasty. Any idea of the dynasty? 
- Manchukuo? 
- He was the last.

290.32.text:
- The Peter O'Toole film by Bertolucci, The Last Emperor. 
- Sorry.

298.16.text: What is the common two-word name of the last Roman emperor of the west?

306.32.text:
- - There was Augustulus... - Constantine. 
- Two names.

319.24.text:
- Romulus Augustulus. 
- Correct, yes, or Romulus Augustus.

323.28.text: And finally, for five points, born in Sandringham in 1895,

326.76.text: which royal figure was officially the last emperor of India?

330.92.text: 1895, so it would have been the last king...

338.64.text: She wouldn't have been emperor anyway.

341.04.text:
- George V or VI? 
- No, George VI.

342.96.text:
- Confident? 
- Still alive, because he died in '52.

346.64.text: - Was Victoria not... - She was the first empress.

349.08.text:
- George VI. 
- Correct, yes. Right, ten points for this.

353.92.text: Which year saw the world's first regular high definition

357.28.text: television service broadcast by the BBC?

359.92.text: It was also the year of the Jarrow March,

362.36.text: the publication of Gone With The Wind,

364.80.text: Fred Perry's final men's singles win at Wimbledon

367.96.text: and the start of the Spanish Civil War.

375.12.text: You get a set of bonuses,

376.32.text: this time on pregnancy in the plays of Shakespeare.

379.60.text: In All's Well That Ends Well, which character,

382.12.text: pretending to be someone else, becomes pregnant after

385.16.text: a midnight assignation with her husband, Bertram?

390.64.text: Sorry. Juliet or Rosalind or something.

393.60.text:
- Do you want Rosalind? Do you fancy Rosalind? 
- Yeah. 
- Rosalind.

398.56.text: Secondly, in Measure For Measure, who's sentenced to death after

401.52.text: it's discovered that his unmarried lover is carrying his child?

407.92.text:
- Claudio. 
- Correct. Finally, in The Winter's Tale,

410.60.text: which character gives birth to a daughter in prison

415.00.text: wrongly believes his old childhood friend to be the infant's father?

420.64.text: We're going to take a picture round now.

422.56.text: For your picture starter, you'll see a map of the world

424.88.text: with ten countries highlighted and ranked.

427.52.text: For ten points, I want you to tell me

430.16.text: to what specific sporting achievement of 2014

448.28.text: No, they're gold medals won at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics.

452.72.text: "Olympics" wasn't precise enough. It's not an achievement.

455.52.text: So we're going to take the picture bonuses in a moment or two.

458.36.text: Ten points for this starter question.

460.36.text: For what to the letters AF stand in the abbreviation AFP,

465.36.text: denoting the protein discovered by Arthur Devries in the blood plasma

469.76.text: of some species of flounder, cod and herring, and in insects such as...?

481.60.text: So you get the picture bonuses.

483.80.text: They are three more maps with countries highlighted

486.60.text: showing the number of medals each of those countries achieved

489.84.text: in a specific discipline at the Winter Olympics in Sochi.

493.84.text: Five points for each event you can name. First.

500.56.text: EMMA: Switzerland's got two. I should know, but it's gone.

503.08.text: What did Britain not get any medals in the Winter Olympics?

507.28.text:
- Skiing, or...? 
- I should really know this.

509.64.text:
- No, we got skiing medals. 
- Bobsleigh, or...?

517.12.text:
- I think cross-country skiing. 
- I think Germany's always... Yep.

519.88.text:
- Cross-country skiing. 
- Correct. Secondly, this event.

523.40.text:
- Look at the 23. That seems important. 
- Oh, um...

528.96.text: Ice skating? Are there 23 kinds of skating?

532.28.text: Well, they've got the 23, so let's go with that.

534.68.text: OK. Do you reckon there's lots of ice skating in Belgium?

537.16.text:
- Ice skating. 
- Erm, no. That's not specific enough. It's speed skating.

540.92.text:
- Oh, blimey. OK. 
- Finally, this, please.

544.80.text:
- Oh, right. What did we win? 
- Oh, skeleton?

554.32.text:
- Skeleton luge. 
- No, it's curling. 
- Curses! 
- Sorry.

557.60.text: So, ten points at stake for this starter question.

559.96.text: Fingers on the buzzers all of you, please.

562.00.text: Anagrams of the name of which landlocked West African country

565.16.text: include a word meaning defensive armour for the body,

569.68.text: the name of a South American capital, and the first name

573.28.text: of the actor who played Oskar Schindler in Spielberg's 1993 film?

580.12.text:
- Mali. 
- Mali is correct, yes. 
- APPLAUSE

587.12.text: So a first set of bonuses for you.

593.24.text: which two punctuation marks form the interrobang,

597.32.text: invented in 1962 to punctuate a question asked in an excited manner?

610.44.text: Is it just a question mark and an exclamation mark together?

615.44.text: Exclamation mark and question mark together.

618.44.text:
- A question mark and an exclamation mark together. 
- Correct.

622.72.text: Secondly, a reversed question mark called a percontation point

626.40.text: was used in the 16th century to signify what type of question,

630.48.text: intended as a statement rather than to elicit an answer?

637.64.text: And finally, the name of which creature in a poem by Lewis Carroll

640.96.text: is shared by a punctuation mark proposed in 2006,

644.40.text: comprising a full stop followed by a tilde and denoting sarcasm?

666.08.text:
- I'll try griffin. 
- Walrus. 
- Griffin or a walrus?

671.96.text:
- A griffin. 
- No, it's a snark. 
- Ah! 
- Of course. 
- Ten points for this.

675.72.text: Around the size of a mistle thrush,

677.28.text: which word is an occasional visitor to the far south of Britain

680.88.text: and it noted for its salmon-coloured plumage

683.44.text: and its distinctive pinkish-brown crest which...?

694.92.text: These bonuses, Hull, are on physics.

697.12.text: Usually named after the German physicist who invented it,

700.16.text: what was the first commercially successful detector

702.68.text: of individual alpha particles and other ionising radiation?

725.36.text: For what do the letters KE of KERMA stand?

728.92.text:
- Kinetic energy? 
- Kinetic energy? I don't know.

733.64.text: Named after a British physicist born in 1905,

736.60.text: in what unit is KERMA measured?

739.40.text: Each is equivalent to one Joule per kilogram.

748.08.text: Named after a scientist. British physicist.

752.28.text: I don't know any British physicists.

758.40.text: Come on, let's have it, please.

763.60.text: No, they're Gray units. Ten points for this.

766.08.text: Patented in 1855, the Bessemer process was a major breakthrough...?

774.52.text: No, I'm afraid you lose five points.

776.52.text:
- Was a major breakthrough in the mass production of which alloy? 
- BUZZER

785.56.text: A set of bonuses for you now on towns north of the river Trent.

789.36.text: In each case, name the town from the description.

791.72.text: All three end with the same five-letter suffix.

794.80.text: Firstly, a town close to the Pennines in East Cheshire.

798.04.text: Formally a centre of the silk industry,

799.76.text: it's associated with the musicians Ian Curtis and John Mayall.

812.08.text: Five-letter suffix, Salford as a four-letter suffix.

814.92.text: Would it be, like, a shire, maybe?

822.40.text: Secondly, a town on the river Colne in West Yorkshire,

825.68.text: the birthplace of Harold Wilson in 1916.

828.44.text: It's noted for its large number of listed buildings

831.56.text: and formed part of the route of the Tour de France in July 2014.

835.36.text: I don't know. Could be Huddersfield?

839.32.text: And finally, a town close to Sherwood Forest in Nottinghamshire.

842.88.text: It's the birthplace of the Olympic swimmer Rebecca Adlington.

856.64.text: Er... It's not a million miles away. It's not far from Sheffield.

864.32.text: Instead of a music round, you're going to have an audio round.

868.08.text: You're about to hear a clip from the inaugural speech

870.36.text: of a president of the United States.

872.12.text: For ten points, please name the president.

875.12.text: 'So first of all, let me assert my...'

881.64.text:
- Franklin Delano Roosevelt is correct, yes. 
- APPLAUSE

887.08.text: That was his first inaugural speech in March 1933,

890.40.text: the last inauguration to take place in March.

898.16.text: You're going to hear three more inauguration speeches since 1933.

902.00.text: In each case, I want the name of the president you can hear.

905.12.text: Five points for each, here's the first.

910.40.text: 'the oath taken by George Washington 200 years ago.

914.88.text: 'And the Bible on which I placed my hand

918.16.text: 'is the Bible on which he placed his.

921.48.text: 'It is right that the memory of Washington be with us today,

925.96.text: 'not only because this is our bicentennial inauguration,

931.16.text: 'but because Washington remains the father of our country.'

944.52.text:
- Nixon. 
- No, it was George Bush Senior. 
- Oh! 
- Here's your second.

949.56.text: 'The world and we have passed the midway point

956.88.text: 'We sense with all our faculties, that forces of good and evil

961.64.text: 'are amassed and armed and opposed as rarely before in history.'

968.20.text:
- Harry Truman. 
- No, that's Dwight Eisenhower.

971.76.text: Your final clip is a pretty short one.

974.96.text: 'And so, my fellow Americans, ask not what your country can do for you,

982.20.text: 'ask what you can do for your country.'

985.80.text:
- I think that was Kennedy. 
- It was indeed, yes.

988.00.text: So ten points for this starter question.

992.72.text: what is the original name of Animal Farm before the rebellion

996.12.text: and the overthrow of its inebriated owner, Mr Jones?

1006.04.text: No. Trinity Hall, one of you buzz.

1016.64.text: of The Red Wheelbarrow, Stoner: A Novel, Arias...?

1028.84.text: Right, your bonuses are on the stylistic device

1034.00.text: in which words derived from the same root are repeated.

1037.28.text: Firstly. "With eager feeding, food doth choke the feeder."

1041.80.text: In which of Shakespeare's histories does John of Gaunt say those words?

1048.36.text: No! Erm... No, sorry. Richard II.

1056.48.text: "No end to the withering of withered flowers,

1059.40.text: "to the movement of pain that is painless and motionless,

1062.16.text: "to the drift of the sea and the drifting wreckage."

1064.84.text: Which poet wrote those lines in a work of 1941?

1077.80.text:
- Dylan Thomas. 
- No, that was TS Eliot in the Dry Salvages.

1081.48.text: And finally, "Diamond me no diamonds, prize me no prizes."

1086.36.text: These words appear in a narrative cycle by which 19th-century poet?

1095.76.text:
- Browning. 
- No, it's Tennyson. Ten points for this.

1098.80.text:
- Divided into three parts entitled Mosque, Caves and Temple...? 
- BUZZER

1105.36.text:
- A Passage To India. 
- Correct. 
- APPLAUSE

1112.24.text: are on Southeast Asian mammals, Trinity Hall.

1115.72.text: Which tropical mammal takes its name from the Malay

1118.24.text: for rolling over because it curls into a ball when threatened?

1122.12.text: It's also known as the scaly anteater.

1131.32.text: The siamang derives its name from the Malay word for black

1134.68.text: and is a member of which family of long-armed arboreal primates?

1148.68.text:
- A family of primates. 
- Oh, right. OK.

1151.08.text:
- Monkeys, apes... 
- It's a specific species we want.

1159.44.text: A binturong is a species of prehensile-tailed arboreal civet.

1164.56.text: To which order of mammals does it belong?

1172.64.text:
- No, they're carnivores. 
- Oh, there we go.

1174.88.text: Right, we're going to take a picture round now.

1179.56.text: Cupid or Eros appears on the left.

1183.04.text: I want you to identify the other two mythological figures depicted.

1203.44.text: So picture bonuses in a moment or two,

1205.92.text: ten points at stake for this starter question.

1209.36.text: Born 1996, Dolly the sheep was cloned from the cells

1227.12.text: No, it was a mammary gland. That's why it was named after Dolly Parton.

1234.60.text: follows Song Of Songs and precedes Jeremiah?

1238.00.text: With 66 chapters, it's one of the longest of the Old Testament.

1245.44.text: No. Anybody want to buzz from Trinity Hall?

- Isaiah? 
- Isaiah is correct, yes.

1256.28.text: So we return to the picture bonuses.

1260.12.text: In Greco-Roman myth, the barren winter months

1263.76.text: were caused by Persephone's annual sojourn

1273.12.text: Firstly for five, this German artist.

1294.00.text:
- Donatello.

1306.20.text:

1313.52.text: of the Eastern Pacific that is administratively

1325.24.text: Your bonuses, Hull, are on schools in literature.

1371.12.text: It sounds like chick lit to me, you see. It's not my field.

1377.40.text: We'd better have an answer, please.

1381.04.text:
- An Unreliable Affair.

1385.52.text: And finally, Sandy Stranger betrays the political leanings

1398.04.text:
- Is it Jean Brodie? 
- Miss Jean Brodie.

1400.08.text: Correct. Four and a half minutes to go, ten points for this.

1402.80.text: What is the common name of the subtropical evergreen tree

1406.28.text: Olea europaea and its edible fruit?

1408.96.text: It's branches appear on the flag of the Republic of Cyprus.

1417.04.text: Your bonuses this time, Trinity Hall, are on plane geometry.

1420.28.text: Which class of plane figures are characterised as quadrilaterals

1424.28.text: with opposite sides of equal length?

1431.76.text:
- Trapezium. 
- Trapezium sounds right to me, or a rhombus?

1438.28.text:
- So it's got two things the same. 
- That just means they're parallel.

1442.24.text:
- What's a parallelepiped, is that something? 
- A rhombus?

1446.20.text:
- Shall we go for rhombus? 
- That's just a square which is tilted.

1448.80.text: But a square is a subclass of it.

1450.64.text: So that's OK, if that's what it means.

1453.80.text: We've forgotten the question. Shall we say rhombus? Rhombus.

1456.84.text: No, it's parallelograms. We were looking for the class.

1459.44.text: The definition of which equilateral parallelogram

1467.56.text:
- So four sides... 
- Let's try parallelepiped.

1476.36.text: And finally, what is the sum

1477.56.text: of the opposite angles in a cyclic quadrilateral?

1489.80.text: No, cos it... The sum will be...?

1491.20.text: The sum of all of them is always 360, so...

1493.68.text:
- Sum of all of them? Didn't he say opposites? 
- Yep.

1496.16.text: So it's going to be less than 360.

1501.24.text: Another starter question. About three minutes to go.

1503.88.text: In medical diagnosis, what instrument is customarily used

1507.64.text: in the procedure known as auscultation?

- Sweet Charity, it was Nights Of Cabiria.

1654.40.text: A set of bonuses for you now

1656.28.text: on words ending in the Latin or Romance diminutive I-L-L-A.

1663.72.text: Firstly, from the Spanish for chamomile or possibly small...

1668.16.text: And at the gong, Hull University have 65,

1678.56.text: Well, Hull, you weren't really on song tonight

1680.60.text: in the way that you've been in some previous shows, but thank you.

1683.44.text:
- We weren't. 
- It was enjoyable to watch them, quite frankly.

1685.96.text: That might have been our mistake.

1687.84.text: No, you were all great fun and none of you teams had to do this

1691.64.text: and I thank you all very much for taking part.

1695.72.text: And many congratulations to you, Trinity Hall.

1698.44.text: You receive no trophy, just a bit of undying glory

1703.60.text: and a glass of revoltingly cheap drink in the green room, no doubt.

1709.04.text: So, great thanks to all the teams who took part despite being

1711.96.text: well old enough to know better. Thank you for watching.

1714.40.text: Next time, we resume the students competition,

1716.64.text:
- but until then, it's goodbye from Hull University. 
- Goodbye.

1720.56.text:
- It's goodbye from Trinity Hall, Cambridge. 
- Goodbye.

1723.20.text: And it's goodbye from me. Goodbye.
